markdownRemark.html:
Introducing Exponentially Weighted Averages

  • Let's say we have some temperature data θ\thetaθ:
θ1=40°F\theta_{1} = 40 \degree\text{F}θ1​=40°F θ2=49°F\theta_{2} = 49 \degree\text{F}θ2​=49°F ......... θn=60°F\theta_{n} = 60 \degree\text{F}θn​=60°F
  • Then our exponentially weighted averages would look like:
v0=0v_{0} = 0v0​=0 v1=0.9v0+0.1θ1v_{1} = 0.9v_{0} + 0.1 \theta_{1}v1​=0.9v0​+0.1θ1​ v2=0.9v1+0.1θ2v_{2} = 0.9v_{1} + 0.1 \theta_{2}v2​=0.9v1​+0.1θ2​ ......... vn=0.9vn−1+0.1θnv_{n} = 0.9v_{n-1} + 0.1 \theta_{n}vn​=0.9vn−1​+0.1θn​
  • Which can be simplified to:
v0=0v_{0} = 0v0​=0 v1=0.9v0+0.1×40=4v_{1} = 0.9v_{0} + 0.1 \times 40 = 4v1​=0.9v0​+0.1×40=4 v2=0.9×4+0.1×49=8.5v_{2} = 0.9 \times 4 + 0.1 \times 49 = 8.5v2​=0.9×4+0.1×49=8.5 ......... vn=0.9vn−1+0.1×60v_{n} = 0.9v_{n-1} + 0.1 \times 60vn​=0.9vn−1​+0.1×60
  • Here, our hyperparameter β=0.9\beta = 0.9β=0.9
  • Here, θt\theta_{t}θt​ represents the ttht^{th}tth temperature value
  • Here, vtv_{t}vt​ represents the weighted average of the ttht^{th}tth temperature value

Defining Exponentially Weighted Averages

  • Exponentially weighted averages are sometimes referred to as exponentially weighted moving averages in statistics
  • The general formula for an exponentially weighted average is:
vt=βvt−1+(1−β)θtv_{t} = \beta v_{t-1} + (1-\beta) \theta_{t}vt​=βvt−1​+(1−β)θt​

Interpreting the Parameters

  • We can think of vtv_{t}vt​ as an average of 11−β\frac{1}{1-\beta}1−β1​ previous days
  • Specifically, we can use whatever units of time (not just days)
  • Roughly, β=0.9\beta = 0.9β=0.9 looks at previous 101010 units of time
  • Roughly, β=0.98\beta = 0.98β=0.98 looks at previous 505050 units of time
  • Roughly, β=0.5\beta = 0.5β=0.5 looks at previous 222 units of time
  • Small values of β\betaβ provide us with a very wiggly curve
  • Large values of β\betaβ provide us with a smooth curve
  • Large values of β\betaβ also cause the curve to shift rightward
  • This is because we're averaging over a larger window of values
  • In other words, a large β\betaβ indicates we're adapting slowly to changes in our data
  • This is because large β\betaβ values are giving more weight to previous values rather than more recent (or current) values

What is Exponential about the Weighted Averages?

  • The data points further away from our current value become exponentially less important
  • This exponential decay is captured by the weights β\betaβ
  • We can rewrite the equations for our example data in the following steps:
vn=0.1θn+0.9vn−1v_{n} = 0.1\theta_{n} + 0.9v_{n-1}vn​=0.1θn​+0.9vn−1​ vn=0.1θn+0.9(0.1θn−1+0.9vn−2)v_{n} = 0.1\theta_{n} + 0.9(0.1\theta_{n-1} + 0.9v_{n-2})vn​=0.1θn​+0.9(0.1θn−1​+0.9vn−2​) vn=0.1θn+0.9(0.1θn−1+0.9(0.1θn−2+0.9vn−2))v_{n} = 0.1\theta_{n} + 0.9(0.1\theta_{n-1} + 0.9(0.1\theta_{n-2} + 0.9v_{n-2}))vn​=0.1θn​+0.9(0.1θn−1​+0.9(0.1θn−2​+0.9vn−2​)) vn=0.1θn+0.9(0.1θn−1+0.9(0.1θn−2+0.9(0.1θn−3+0.9vn−3)))v_{n} = 0.1\theta_{n} + 0.9(0.1\theta_{n-1} + 0.9(0.1\theta_{n-2} + 0.9(0.1\theta_{n-3} + 0.9v_{n-3})))vn​=0.1θn​+0.9(0.1θn−1​+0.9(0.1θn−2​+0.9(0.1θn−3​+0.9vn−3​))) vn=0.1θn⏟gt=1+0.1×0.9θn−1⏟gt=2+0.1×0.92θn−2+0.1×0.93vn−3v_{n} = \underbrace{0.1\theta_{n}}_{g_{t=1}} + \underbrace{0.1 \times 0.9 \theta_{n-1}}_{g_{t=2}} + 0.1 \times 0.9^{2} \theta_{n-2} + 0.1 \times 0.9^{3}v_{n-3}vn​=gt=1​0.1θn​​​+gt=2​0.1×0.9θn−1​​​+0.1×0.92θn−2​+0.1×0.93vn−3​

  • As previously stated, we roughly look at the previous 101010 units of time when β=0.9\beta = 0.9β=0.9
  • Here, we can see ggg roughly becomes equal to 000 when t=10t=10t=10
  • In other words, we're saying temperatures that are 111111, 121212, or more days away from the current day don't have much influence on our current temperature

Advantages and Disadvantages

  • An advantage of using exponentially weighted averages is the performance boost

    • If we were to average values using a moving window, we would need to save the values and averages of previous days
    • By averaging values using exponential weights, we only need to save the current vtv_{t}vt​ in memory

  • A disadvantage of using exponentially weighted averages is the decrease in accuracy

    • If we were to average values using a moving window, we could accurately average all of the previous days
    • By averaging values using exponential weights, we can only look at the previous vtv_{t}vt​

Describing Bias Correction

  • By setting v0=0v_{0}=0v0​=0, we add some degree of bias to our model

  • Since v1,v2,...,vnv_{1}, v_{2},...,v_{n}v1​,v2​,...,vn​ are all based on v0v_{0}v0​, then the earlier values of vvv will be slightly smaller than expected
  • As vvv increases, this bias will become negligible
  • However, we should still correct for this bias, since earlier values of vvv will be underestimated
  • We can do this by transforming each vtv_{t}vt​ term:
vt∗=vt1−β2v_{t}^{*} = \frac{v_{t}}{1-\beta^{2}}vt∗​=1−β2vt​​

tldr

  • Exponentially weighted averages are sometimes referred to as exponentially weighted moving averages in statistics
  • The general formula for an exponentially weighted average is:
vt=βvt−1+(1−β)θtv_{t} = \beta v_{t-1} + (1-\beta) \theta_{t}vt​=βvt−1​+(1−β)θt​
  • We can think of vtv_{t}vt​ as an average of 11−β\frac{1}{1-\beta}1−β1​ previous days
  • Specifically, we can use whatever units of time (not just days)
  • Roughly, β=0.9\beta = 0.9β=0.9 looks at previous 101010 units of time
  • Roughly, β=0.98\beta = 0.98β=0.98 looks at previous 505050 units of time
  • Roughly, β=0.5\beta = 0.5β=0.5 looks at previous 222 units of time
